Award.AwardTitle: Beyond Bridging: Co-Education of Preservice and Inservice Elementary Teachers In Science and Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Arizona is partnering with the Tucson Unified School District to implement and study a professional community designed to alleviate the mismatch between the expectations of student teachers in mathematics and science and their mentor in-service teachers. This vexing problem often arises when student teachers expect to implement reform-based pedagogies while their mentor teachers insist on traditional approaches. The project is creating a "third space," a professional community that includes 40 pre-service and 50 in-service teachers, university scientists and mathematicians, science and mathematics education faculty, and school district administrators. The third space is providing a neutral forum for the exchange of perspectives on issues of pedagogy with the expectation that student teachers would implement inquiry-based science and problem-solving mathematics pedagogies with the knowledgeable support of their mentor teachers. The project is being implemented in two low-income, culturally and linguistically diverse elementary schools with a comparison school used as a control.

The evaluation/research component is a qualitative study led by Horizon Research, Inc. The fundamental research question is whether the third space model establishes interpretive systems that foster enactment of inquiry-based and problem-solving teaching practices. Data collection will include all participants in the third space forum, but focuses on the pre-service and in-service teachers through written products and discussions of lesson design activities, videotapes of teaching by pre-service and in-service teachers, and analysis of comments made in a web-based forum. Instruments to be used are the Reform Teaching Observation Protocol (RTOP), the Experiences Patterns Explanations (EPE) framework, and the Inquiry-Application Instructional Model (I-AIM).

The main product of this project is the third space model and the research that supports its success. The model will be disseminated broadly and if replicated widely, it would represent a major improvement in the professional development of teachers in the areas of inquiry-based science and problem-solving mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Students in teacher preparation programs (preservice teachers) are learning from both university (or other teacher preparation program) faculty and the teachers in the school classrooms in which they do their practicum work (mentor teachers). Principle-based discourses, usually situated in the university-based education courses, focus on general, research-based knowledge, rules, or approaches designed to be applied broadly to a wide variety of situations. The practical-based discourses of schools come from the rich, context-based knowledge and experience of teachers in classrooms and focus on addressing the daily pressures, tensions, and realities of teachers and students in schools. Teachers, whether students in teacher preparation programs or experienced classroom teachers, will only utilize principle-based teaching methods in their classrooms if they come to see these approaches as solutions to the practical issues they face in planning and conducting lessons with students. They need opportunities to talk about the research-based principles and their teaching, and they need these opportunities as they plan, as they teach, and as they reflect upon teaching.

The Beyond Bridging project designed a new co-education model of elementary teacher preparation to address this important issue. The model consists of three essential components: 1) Joint preservice teacher and mentor teacher learning events provide opportunities for working together such as analyzing curriculum materials for lesson planning and conducting clinical interviews with children about their mathematics thinking. 2) Professional development on mentoring helps mentor teachers adopt a co-learning approach instead of positioning themselves to their preservice teachers as experts telling them how to teach. 3) Instructional support liaisons work with both the preservice and mentor teachers in their classrooms, helping to connect the principles learning in university courses to the practical issues of classroom teaching.

The Beyond Bridging Model differs from other attempts to “bridge” teacher preparation program and school classrooms in two important ways. First, rather than simply connecting people or places, the model involves the preservice and mentor teachers in joint sense-making activities that enable them to shape their teaching practices in way that situates principles in practices in the classroom. Second, the model works with preservice and mentor (classroom) teachers together, instead of using the more common approach of working with them separately.

The Beyond Bridging Model is a pragmatic model that supports preservice and mentor teachers in learning with and from each other how to teach problem-solving mathematics and inquiry science, thus improving instructional practices for all at the same time. The model goes beyond bridging the gap between university-based coursework and classroom teaching, increasing the frequency of problem-solving mathematics and inquiry science teaching practices, and thus positively impacting student achievement in mathematics and science.
